III.Facility Identification
The Dawn Foods facility is located at 1340 Sycamore Road in Manteno, Illinois.  The facility is a producer of custom and branded snack cakes and muffins primarily for retail distribution. 

The NAICS code for the facility is 311813. Many areas of the plant are refrigerated to preserve ingredients and products.   

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating baked goods ingredients and products. 

The anticipated ammonia charge for the refrigeration system has been calculated at 12,951 pounds.  The ammonia refrigeration system was originally put into service during the fall of 2007, however, at that time the system was charged with approximately 9,000 pounds.  Because the amount of ammonia was under the 10,000 pound threshold, an RMP was not submitted at that time.  A recent addition to the ammonia refrigeration system will result in approximately 3,000 additional pounds being added to the system.  

The refrigeration system is used to cool process rooms, holding freezers, coolers, docks, and blast freezers.  This refrigeration system uses ammonia refrigerant in a two (2) stage evaporation/condensation cycle.  The ?low pressure? equipment includes one (1) spiral freezer and two (2) storage freezer evaporators, one (1) low temperature pump receiver (V-4) with ammonia pumps (AP1 and AP2) and oil pot (V-5), and two (2) low temperature booster compressors (RC-1 and RC-2).  The ?high pressure? equipment includes two (2) +60 - 70 muffin room evaporators, three (3) +60 ? 80 autobake cooler evaporators, one (1) +40 finished product staging evaporator, one (1) +40 vestibule evaporator, two (2) +70 dry bulk cooler evaporators, one (1) +70 cup room evaporator, one (1) water chiller, two (2) +60

? 70 tempering room evaporators, two (2) +60 ? 70 receiving dock evaporators, and two (2) +60 ? 70 cookie mixing room cooler evaporators, one high temperature pump receiver (V-2) with ammonia pumps (AP3 and AP4) and oil pot (V-3), two (2) high stage compressors (RC-3 and RC-4).  The ?high pressure? equipment includes two (2) evaporative condensers, one (1) high pressure/thermosyphon receiver, and associated piping.

VI.General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The first audit of the PSM program will occur by July 31, 2010, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
?Employee Participation ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee part

icipation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
?Process Safety Information ? Dawn Foods maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of July 29, 2009.
?Process Hazard Review ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Dawn Foods conducted a thorough, initial, PHA study for the refrigeration system during July and August, 2007.
?Operating Procedures ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Dawn Foods developed initial operating procedures for the refrigeration system during August 2007.  Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.
 ?Training ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
?Management of Change ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
?Pre-Startup Review ? Dawn F

oods has updated a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.  Specifically, a pre-startup safety review was conducted on August 6, 2009 for the addition that resulted in a total quantity of ammonia on-site that exceeded the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.
?Mechanical Integrity ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Dawn Foods formalized maintenance procedures for the refrigeration system during August 2007.
?Contractor Qualifications ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers? safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Dawn Foods and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.
?Incident Investigation ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
?Compliance Audit ? Dawn Foods has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Dawn Foods PSM/RMP practices and procedures are

adequate and are being followed.  An initial compliance audit will be conducted by July 31, 2010.  
?Hot Work Permits ? Dawn Foods has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Hot work permits/procedures were last reviewed on July 28, 2009.

VII.Five-Year Accident History
The Dawn Foods facility has not yet charged the ammonia refrigeration system and therefore has not experienced an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VIII.Emergency Response Program
Dawn Foods has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Upon facility start-up, Dawn Foods will communicate and train facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and will interact (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Manteno Fire Department. 

Upon facility start-up, Dawn Foods will coordinate their EAP with the Kankakee County ESDA and the Manteno Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing each aforementioned agency with a copy of our EAP, providing each with a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Manteno Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilities operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Manteno Fire Department personnel.

Dawn Foods? hazardous materials response team will be responsible for investigating and assisting the Manteno Fire Department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. 

The facility has three (3) windsocks onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is include

d in Appendix E. 

IX.Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.

X.Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Dawn Foods operations. Dawn Foods is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Dawn Foods. 

XI.Management Program
Dawn Foods has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Fred Alexander, General Manager, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
